utterances: The art world's a pretty conservative place, and so if you call yourself a feminist, you tend to get blacklisted by a lot of people.
Mann says many young women feel they don't need feminism because they believe they have their rights.
Artist Judy Chicago is probably best known for her work, ""The Dinner Party,"" which is an immense, triangular table with place-settings of the names of historically important women.
Chicago thinks these young artists may have a rude awakening in their 40s.
It's like a glass ceiling.
It's just exactly like it is in the corporate work.
It's no different, actually.
So it's deceptive to young women because at entry level, it looks like there's no problem.

While more than 50 percent of art-school graduates are women, there's little disagreement about the fact that they are under-represented in major museum collections and as subjects for retrospectives.
At the Museum of Modern Art in New York, less than 20 percent of the collection is work by female artists.
The MOCA exhibition may be a sign that there is renewed interest in feminism among artists.
Earlier this month, there was a sold-out symposium on the topic at MOMA in New York.
The Brooklyn Museum is about to open a center for feminist art, and many of those artists would agree that the revolution that began in the 1960s is still underway.
Laura Sydell, NPR News.
The trial for the militants who seized the Malheur National Wildlife Refuge in rural Oregon last winter is close to wrapping up.
The militants were led by Ammon Bundy.
And they were protesting the federal government's control of public lands.
This has been a high-profile trial about an occupation that, as it happened, tore apart the nearby little town of Burns, Ore.
Reporting on the saga were NPR's Kirk Siegler and reporter Amanda Peacher with Oregon Public Broadcasting, who both recently traveled back to Burns.
Good morning to you both.
Good morning, Renee.
Good morning, Renee.
So, Kirk, take us back to the basics.
How did this start?
Well, this started when Ammon Bundy and his militia followers, they had initially come to the area to protest the government's treatment of two local ranchers who had pled guilty to arson charges.
Now, Ammon of course is the son of Cliven Bundy, the Nevada rancher who's at the center of this sort of lands movement.
And the Bundys want to turn over all federal land in the West to local control.
And so this protest turned into a much larger armed occupation out at the refuge in an attempt to do just that.
Amanda, you were on the ground for most of the 41-day siege.
What was it like for that community there, that rural community?
Well, there were a few people in the community who supported the militants and the idea of the siege.
But the vast majority of the community wanted these people to go.
The militants were from outside.
They were strangers to this small town.
And it created a very tense environment in Burns.
So Burns, Ore., was thrust into the international media spotlight along with the entire siege.
Not, though, much has been said about it at this trial.
What is it like there now?
Well, that's exactly what we wanted to find out, Renee.
So we went back and started our reporting at the recent Harney County Fair.
The Harney County Fair is probably the biggest event of the year here.
There's a rodeo, there are 4-H kids showing their pigs and rabbits that they've been raising all year long.
And the main event, the parade through downtown Burns.
There's a float in support of the local sheriff, Dave Ward.
He was one of the most vocal opponents of the armed occupation.
(Over loudspeaker) Dave Ward is a true Harney County hero.
And then another float passes with several people who supported the Bundys.
They're dressed up as ranchers, loggers and miners.
And there's a sign on the side that says, these are the endangered species.
That's a riff on the Endangered Species Act.
It's a favorite target of the Bundys.
Now, on this float is Cheryl Smith (ph), who doesn't think the Bundys did anything wrong.
That's it.
Nice clue, too.
Plus prate, P-R-A-T-E.
For instance, new infections are dropping in some groups, but not in others.
Infections among men who have sex with men have been steadily increasing.
Twenty-seven years into the epidemic that started in this group, gay and bisexual men still account for more than half of all new cases.
The data really confirmed that the most severe impact of the epidemic continues to be among gay and bisexual men of all races and among black men and women.
Blacks account for 45 percent of new HIV infections.
Their infection rate is seven times that of whites.
The infection rate among Hispanics are three times higher.
That, experts say, is where more HIV prevention money needs to be spent.
But Ronald Johnson of the AIDS Action Council says funding has been going down.
When you have nearly flat funding for HIV treatment and care and reduced funding for HIV prevention, it means that we are not doing what we need to do.
Johnson says, with inflation, the CDC's HIV prevention budget has declined about 20 percent over the past six years.
Richard Knox, NPR News.
Imagine someone saying this, after the bee stinged me, I put on some smelly lotion, it really stinked.
A functional illiterate or a child or a non-English speaker who's unaccustomed to irregular English verbs just sticking -ed on the end of every verb?
How about an English speaker of the future, say, the year 2500?
There is an article in the journal Nature today that studies the speed at which irregular English verbs tend to become regular English verbs.
And it concludes that irregular past tenses like stung, stunk, sang, struck will be on their way out before the next millennium.
On the other hand, some other irregular past tense verbs like did, gave and thought are likely to have more than 10 millennia to go.

Why some words change and others don't, or do so much more slowly, is a question addressed by two articles in Nature and they follow an introductory article by Tecumseh Fitch of St. Andrews University, who joins us now from Scotland.
Welcome to the program.
Hello, Robert.

And first, let's take the article on ""The Future of the Past Tense."" The authors - Erez Lieberman, Jean-Baptiste Michel, Joe Jackson, Tina Tang and Martin Nowak - they come up with a formula about irregular verbs, how they tend to become regular and which verbs are more likely to change faster than the others.
What is it?
Well, the regularization depends on the frequency of word usage in the following specific way: The half-life of an irregular verb scales as the square root of its usage frequency.
And I know that might sound a little confusing.
Yeah.
A little confusing.
What it really means is the more rare a word is, the more likely it is that it will become regularized.
And by regularized, in this case, we mean instead of it being - present tense, I know, past tense, I knew it - some people next to this one will say I knowed, and it hasn't happened to that verb yet.
But they would say the reason it hasn't is because we say I know so often and I knew so often.
That's right.
And to take another example, the past tense of help was once holp.
And now, of course, we all say help, helped.
So that's a great example of a relatively common verb that actually has become regularized in the recent history of the English language.
Recent history would be still measured in centuries in this case…
Yes, yes.
…as we're doing it.

And what we're looking at is words that came down to us in one form from old English in the middle and they say that the investigators here have examined huge sources of language that have been written over the centuries to see when people said what is the past tense of which verb?
Yeah.
We have a corpus of Old English, which is relatively small, a much more significant body of written work from Middle English and of course, a huge amount, an ever growing amount in Modern English.
They looked at actually 177 different verbs across those different time periods in order to come up with this relationship.
And help-holp, notwithstanding, the most common verbs in the English language - to be, to have, to go, to say - are irregular.
They don't go past tense as with adding an -ed.
So we use them so often, the old usage survives.
Apparently.
I think anyone who's learned a foreign language will recognize that's the same in most languages, that we find the same thing in German or Italian or French.
That verbs like to be, to have, to take, to go tend to be irregular - typically irregular in all those different languages.
Now, the other article in Nature by Mark Pagel, Quentin Atkinson and Andrew Meade addresses a similar point.

It's why is it that in languages that descended from Indo-European - words for some things like water or the number two are remarkably similar from one language to the next, while words for other things, like in animals tail, say, are quite different.
And again, it's about which words are more common?
Yes.
So again, common words are resistant to change or resistant to replacement whereas uncommon words seemed to be rather easily substituted by new forms.
Why does language change at all, that is, why are we not saying I holp or I used to holp, or why are we not all saying whatever the Indo-European word for a tail was?
Well, I think that's really one of the fascinating, deep questions that both of these papers raise, but don't actually answer.
The most traditional reason for language change is essentially an accumulation of error similar to what you might find in random evolution - in biological evolution.
And now officials across the region are saying time's up.
NPR's Laura Sullivan reports.
